_exec_summary.SummaryText:
KOCH NITROGEN COMPANY

Huntington Terminal 
Huntington, Indiana

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
FOR 
THE RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN (RMPlan)


Introduction and Policies

Koch Nitrogen Company (KNC) is committed to managing all operations in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of employees, customers, contractors and the public while fully complying with applicable laws and regulations.  KNC¿s management philosophy goals are achieved through the implementation of the Environmental Health and Safety Management Systems, by the personal commitments of employees and contractors, and by open communication with employees, customers, neighbors, and regulators.

The purpose of this Risk Management Plan is to provide information about operations at the terminal, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, emergency response plans in the event an accidental release should occur, the five-year accident history of the terminal and planned changes to improve safety at the terminal.


Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

The Huntington Terminal is one of many facilities owned and operated by KNC that supply anhydrous ammonia to the Midwest farming area where it is used primarily as a fertilizer. At the terminal, anhydrous ammonia is delivered by pipeline and stored until it is loaded on to trucks or railcars for distribution.  

Anhydrous ammonia is the only toxic substance regulated under the Risk Management Program (RMP) that is present at the Huntington Terminal in amounts above threshold quantity.  Propane is stored at the facility; however, it is used strictly as a fuel and as such is exempt from RMP reporting.  The terminal is classified as Program Level 3 under the regulation. 


Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs in place at the facility are part of the high standards striven for by KNC.  These high standards include:

·Operating in compliance with required e

nvironmental permits and regulations. 
·Operating and maintaining the assets in such a manner that unintentional releases are minimized.
·Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that the small releases associated with normal operation and maintenance will be minimized to the extent possible.
·Correcting non-compliance found by regular audits of the facility.


Prevention Program

The Huntington Terminal is operating under the guidelines of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Program.  Ongoing analysis of the potential hazards of the process, detailed training of employees, and emphasis on safety has helped avoid any serious chemical release accidents over the last 5 years.  Part of this program has also involved identifying and taking steps to avoid potential accidental chemical releases.  A few examples of the prevention features implemented at this facility include: 

·Minimizing the possibility that flare combustion of ammonia vapors would be interrupted by having continuous pilots.
·Minimizing the possibility that combustion of ammonia vapors would be interrupted by having a backup generator.
·Minimizing the possibility that combustion of ammonia vapors would be interrupted by having back up fuel (propane) for the flare.
·Providing annual truck loading training to ensure driver safety.
·Preventive maintenance and testing of vessels through the Mechanical Integrity program helps to ensure that structural failures do not occur in process equipment.
·Providing emergency shutdown buttons at the truck loading area that can be activated by KNC personnel or the truck driver in case of an ammonia release.
·Ammonia sensors in the process areas and on the property to detect ammonia and activate the Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) monitoring system if the threshold for ammonia is exceeded.
·Monitoring level alarms and pressure in process vessels through SCADA to help prevent a release of ammoni

a.
·Providing annual truck loading training to ensure driver safety.
·Security guards are on duty monitoring the terminal.
·Installing cameras and motion detectors that alarm at a central control room in Wichita to alert that intruders may have entered the facility. 


Five-Year Accident History 

The Huntington Terminal has had one incident occur during the last five years that is reportable in the five-year accident history maintained under the RMP regulations  On December 15, 2000, a threaded pipe connection on a rail car loading rack failed during the loading of a railcar that caused the release of approximately 850 pounds of anhydrous ammonia to the air.  The loading process was immediately shutdown by KNC personnel and the rail rack piping was isolated.  There were no injuries or deaths as a result of this incident.  Nearby businesses were evacuated as a result of this release.  The Huntington Terminal employees followed proper emergency response procedures to ensure that on-site and off-site impacts were minimized.  


Emergency Response Program

The terminal will continue to conduct emergency response preparedness activities and coordinate any emergency response actions necessary for the Huntington Terminal with the Huntington City Fire Department.  Also involved in emergency response for the facility would be the Huntington County Sheriff and, as appropriate, the Memorial Hospital located in Huntington, the United REMC Utility Company and the Allen County HAZMAT Team.  The Huntington Terminal Manager is responsible for coordinating the emergency actions.  A specific Emergency Response Plan for the terminal is in place and that plan has been coordinated with local officials.  The Emergency Response Program provides the essential planning for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.


Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Compliance with the RMP Prevention Program, coupled with the Environmental Health and Safe

ty Management Systems, forms the framework for continuous safety improvement.  Some of the key components of the safety program are:

·The Management of Change provisions ensure that the potential safety and health impacts of any change made to process chemicals, technology, equipment or procedures are considered.
·The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) provisions serve as a tool to ensure timely evaluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continual improvements in safety standards.
·The Mechanical Integrity provisions ensure that process equipment and instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous releases, thereby serving as an integral part of the safety program. 

Specific actions that will be taken in the future to improve the level of safety at the terminal include:

·Internal and third party compliance audits will ensure that the level of safety protection at the terminal is periodically evaluated for improvements.
·An ongoing dialogue with the Huntington County Emergency Management Director or his designate will ensure a constant state of readiness to respond to any potential emergencies, as well as a means to implement improvements as the need develops. 

All interested citizens or community organizations are encouraged to contact the Huntington County Emergency Management Director for the latest information on emergency response for the county.  The terminal coordinates its response capabilities and personnel with those of the county on an ongoing basis.
